titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Saturday.

Began the version of the 27th. Psalm— I went to Boston with Mrs Adams, Mary Roberdeau and Charles— Called at Gray and Bowens, where I left twenty pages of manuscript of the chapter for the American Annual Register— I told Mr Gray that I would furnish him with a continuation of the manuscript as fast as he would print it, to the end of the chapter, and I requested him to send out to me to Quincy the proof sheets, as fast as they should be printed for correction—which he promised to do.— I called twice at Richardson and Lord’s to see Mr Lord; but he was not there— Then at Hilliard and Gray’s, to enquire if they had any copies remaining of my Lectures on Rhetoric and Oratory.— Hilliard (or the man who kept the shop[)] told me they had only five copies remaining— That they had sometime since sold a number of copies at Auction which they had received thirty cents for a Volume— He said it was what they called a dull book; like Campbells philosophy of Rhetoric— They would not sell— He shewed me the accounts of their stock for several years in succession, where the numbers of copies of each book on hand, were set down, and for four or five years in sequence the number of sets of my Lectures was the same— He said that at the auction sale they had sold at thirty cents a volume— I asked him if he would take that for all the copies he had remaining. He said he would, and I took them all— Four copies in boards: but he chose to retain one copy which was bound. I told him I had thoughts of printing another Edition of them. He said that books of that kind, all elementary books upon Science, had no sale, unless adopted as Class-books at some public school or College. I went to Eastburn’s shop he was not there; but afterwards met me at Charles’s house— There had been some complaints from Editors of Newspapers, at the Copy-right taken out of the Eulogy; and an attempt in the Boston Courier, to impress the belief that the Copy-right had been taken, for my own benefit— Eastburn said Buckingham the Editor of the Courier knew this to be false, for he had told him how the fact was.— I desired him to give notice in that paper that the Editor of any Newspaper, in the United States might publish in his journal the whole, or any part of the Eulogy at his pleasure; and told him I did not believe there was one who would avail himself of the privilege when he should have it— I dined at Alexander H. Everett’s with a party of fifteen or sixteen gentlemen; among whom were the two French Commissioners of the Government Tocqueville and de Beaumont, who have been sent to this Country to visit and examine the Prisons; and prison discipline— After dinner I called at Mr Frothingham’s, where the Ladies and Charles had dined; and whence we returned in the Evening to Quincy.
2. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney, in the morning from John 4.34 “Jesus saith unto them, my meat is to do the will of him that sent me, and to finish his work.” After the service the Communion was administered—of which I partook— The afternoon Service was from Ecclesiastes 7.10. [“]Say not thou, what is the cause that the former days were better than these? for thou dost not enquire wisely concerning this.” Mr Whitney thinks that the world is improving—that the present times are better than the past, and that the future times are likely to be better than the present; and I am of the same opinion— Louisa C. Smith dined with us, as also did Mr
Degrand who walked out from Boston— He told me, that the Anti-Masonic Convention recently held at Baltimore, had nominated William Wirt, heretofore, Attorney General of the United States, as a Candidate for the next Election to the Presidency of the United States, and Amos Ellmaker of Pennsylvania, for the Office of Vice-President. Degrand returned to Boston this Evening; and I walked with Charles to my brothers where I found Company— I wrote a Letter to Harlow Hard, to be sent with a copy of my Lectures, for the use of the Websterian Library at Charlestown, Clark County, Indiana.
3. V. Monday.

Charles went to Boston, and came back this Evening. Mr Ellis of Dedham called and gave me some Apples—Golden pippins, of good size, and perfectly sound, but not yet ripe. He requested me to keep them some days, till they should turn yellow before tasting them— He brought them in consequence of my having told him that I had seen no golden pippins for several years, and that I believed the species was nearly or quite extinct.— In my youth I thought it the finest flavoured apple that grew; and it was in high reputation— It has now become exceedingly rare; and was so in England when I was last there— Deacon Spear and his brother were here, about the fencing of my Cherry-tree lot— There were visits from Mrs Edward Miller, and Miss Baxter. I wrote to Mr Duponceau at Philadelphia.
4. IV:30. Tuesday.

Mrs. Adams, went with Isaac H. Adams to a fishing party at the Creek— I finished a Letter which I had several days since begun to S. L. Southard, and left, broke off in the middle— My nephew the Lieutenant was here; and took with him, Gimbrede’s drawing from Stewart’s last Portrait of my father.— That Portrait was painted at my special desire, about two years before my father’s decease and when he was in his ninetieth year— My purpose was to have a likeness of him in his last days, by the first Painter in this Country. It has been a source of much gratification to me, that this was effected— The picture is an excellent likeness, and one of the best that Stewart ever painted— After my father’s death, I had a copy of it painted by Stewart himself which is at Washington— Charles has the Original in his house at Boston. The same Summer when my father died, (1826) Gimbrede copied it in black Crayons—from which he has since made an engraving.— The drawing is very good— The engraving very indifferent— I have taken 12 Copies of the Print, and Gimbrede offered me the drawing for 25 dollars— I declined taking it at that price—but the Lieutenant has taken it— He has also a small portrait of me in Crayons, taken at the Hague by Schmidt, in 1783. when I was 16 years old; which I gave to my Sister and she to her daughter Mrs De Wint; who gave it to the Lieutenant at his visit to her last Summer— I planted this afternoon four rows of Acorns in my nursery. And this Evening we attended a party at Mr George W. Beale’s— Mr Thomas Greenleaf who had been to Boston, told me, that my old friend, and my fathers pupil Jonathan Mason was lying at the point of death— I saw him in perfect health at President Quincy’s on Commencement day.
5. V. Wednesday.

Early this morning, Mr Francis Brinley, and Mr Amasa Walker, came as a Committee from the Anti-Masonic State Convention, consisting of Committees from the several County Conventions in the Commonwealth, and sitting at Boston, and announced that they had yesterday, unanimously agreed to nominate me for election to the Office of Governor of this Commonwealth for the ensuing year.— The election is to take place on the second Monday of the next Month— It is the first election under the adopted Amendment of the Constitution of the State, by which the political year is to commence in January, and the Legislature are to hold only one annual Session— They said they hoped I would accept the nomination; and that the
Convention yet in Session were anxious to receive my answer as soon as possible— I desired them to assure the Convention of the grateful sense that I entertained of the confidence manifested in their offer of nomination; and of my regret that I felt myself bound in duty to decline it. Governor Lincoln was personally my friend, and I approved the general course of his administration. I therefore could not permit my name to be set up in opposition to him, and I had earnestly hoped that the Antimasonic Convention would have nominated him— I ought in candour to tell them that I approved his answer to the Letter which had been addressed to him by their Committee— I thought his opinions against the Masonic Institution clearly and strongly expressed— There were indeed some passages relating to the course of the Anti-masons, which seemed to import censure upon them, but I believed it was not intended, and might easily be explained— I had hoped the Anti-masons would be satisfied with his Anti-masonic Declaration and had no doubt that in the course of the year events would have occurred which would have fixed him entirely with them.— Walker said it was to be regretted that they had taken other views; but as they had done so, he presumed they would in the event of my declining make another nomination— Mr Brinley made no remark upon my observations but expressed a wish that I would give my answer in writing— I requested them to call again in half an hour, which they did, and I immediately wrote my answer— But they returned before I had time to have a copy of it made— I told them that to avoid detaining them, I would give them the Letter without waiting to take a copy— That if they should publish it, I would take my copy from the publication, but if not, I should request them to furnish me with a copy, which they promised should be done— I was at an Evening party at Mrs Baxters where we met Messrs. Rowe, Horner, Baldwin, John A. Williams and Hallett, with Mr Whitney and his family only of the Quincy Society— Mr Williams is a young Clergyman, a Son of the late Thomas Williams of Roxbury, now preaching at the Roxbury Church. I had a very dark and miry walk home with Charles.— Finished this morning the version of the 27th Psalm.
6. IV:45. Thursday

I began the version of the 28th. Psalm and in the afternoon went with I. H. Adams in search of Acorns— We gathered about half a peck of black and red Oak Acorns, from Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s grounds, and on returning home, although it was after sunset and darkening I planted in the garden a row of 60 Red Oak, and a row of 60 Black Oak Acorns. The rest I left in the bag; but from all my experience I am convinced that ripe Acorns and Chestnuts ought not after being gathered to be exposed to the air a single day. If not planted on the same day upon which they are gathered, they should be covered with earth, in a box or barrel: or in a hole dug in the Earth— Mr G. W. Beale and his daughter Ann spent the Evening here— I am yet engaged upon the Chapter for the American Annual Register, and yesterday and this day wrote a Letter to Dr. Waterhouse, at Cambridge.
7. IV:15. Friday.

Deacon Daniel Spear sold this day the wood standing upon my lot called Lawyers Common, and I walked over there to see the progress of the Sale— There was a larger number of purchasers than usual and the sales were brisk. The price of wood for fuel is in this neighbourhood at present nearly double its usual average—occasioned by the scarcity of Snow last Winter in the State of Maine whence the principal supply of fire-wood for the Boston market generally comes— Here, and along the Sea-Coast Southward to North-
Carolina, there fell last winter at least double the average quantity of Snow— While Northward, and in the State of Maine there was no Snow at all— The want of Snow prevented the transportation of firewood from the forests in which it is cut down, to the landing places on Kennebeck River where it is usually embarked and very little of it has been brought to Boston this Season.— This has raised the price of standing wood here.— I observed again the growth of young Oaks and Walnut Trees, coming up in the place of the Pines and Cedars cut down on part of this Lot two years ago— This natural phenomenon has been observed by the writers upon woods and forests; but has never been accounted for; and is to me so surprising as to make me incredulous almost of my own observations. On my return homewards I gathered a pocketful of black and grey Oak Acorns in my Middle and Druid Pastures;—which I planted together with some red Oak Acorns in my Nursery, near the central Apple-tree— My wife went with most of the family on a fishing party at the Creek. I wrote to my Son John.
8. IV:45. Saturday.

Finished my version of the 28th. Psalm. Mrs Adams, with Charles, his wife and child, and Miss Roberdeau went to Boston this Morning; dined at Mr Frothinghams and returned home this Evening.— Alpheus Spear was here this morning with a load of wood. After dinner I walked with Isaac H. Adams to Mount Wollaston, where we gathered perhaps a bushel of black chesnut and grey oak Acorns; and a few white walnuts.— Met Luther Spear and Alpheus at Rock-Island, round which we went, and the fencing of which is an object of some difficulty and expence— Alpheus Spear also wants me to new shingle entirely the roof of the barn. He has had an application from a man who wants to cut down all the young growing birch trees for hoops.— Half of Rock Island, and all the large Oak trees upon it, which I supposed to belong to me, are the property of the Town of Quincy— I received a Letter from W. H. Weld of East Middleborough in the County of Plymouth respecting an application from that place for a Post-Office; which I answered— As I also did one from Mr Alexander B. Johnson of Utica, concerning my niece Mrs Susan B. Clark.— And a printed circular Letter from Messrs. J. B. Matthews, Jonn. M. Wainwright, Albert Gallatin and John Delafield at New-York, inviting me to attend a literary Convention to meet in that City on the first day of November next— There was a Convention of the same kind held there the last Autumn. Their object is, conference upon subjects of Literature and Science.— I have intended to proceed to the South this year, the first week in November— I now determined to go on one week earlier, and answered the Letter of the Committee accepting their invitation— It will make it necessary for me to leave home on the 28th. of this Month.
9. IV:30. Sunday.

Began the version of the 29th. Psalm.— Heard Dr Lowell of Boston; in the morning from 2. Timothy 1.5. “When I call to remembrance the unfeigned faith that is in thee which dwelt first in thy grandmother (Lois) and thy mother (Eunice) and I am perswaded that in thee also.” and in the afternoon from Colossians 3.3. “For ye are dead—and your life is hid with Christ in God.” Dr Lowell dined with us.— His discourse of the Morning upon the influence of mothers upon the characters of their children was instructive and affecting. I wrote two Letters this day; one to I K. Tefft of Savannah, from whom I received nearly a year since a Letter, and another last Summer requesting an autograph of my own, and one of my father, and any others of persons distinguished during our revolutionary War— I had laid aside his Letter with the
intention of collecting among my father’s papers a number of autographs such as were desired by Mr Tefft before I should answer him—but my time has been so much absorbed with other occupations, that I have not been able to make the collections; and I have concluded to answer the Letter without more delay. I sent enclosed in it a copy in my fathers own hand writing and signed by him of his answer to the young men of Boston in 1798— My other Letter was to Alexander Townsend in answer to one from him upon his hearing that I had declined the Anti-masonic nomination for Governor— We had music this Evening—Miss Roberdeau sung the 100th. Psalm to the Tune of Denmark, and the Hymn—“How beauteous are their feet[”]—one of the best of Watts’s.
10. III:45. Monday.

I was unwell in the Night, and up half an hour before my usual time this morning. I answered a Letter received from General Joseph G. Swift— After dinner I planted 3 rows of grey oak Acorns in the Nursery in the second bed north of the central tree— This Evening we read a number of passages of Poetry by American Poets—Percival—Halleck—Dana—Bryant—Peabody—Willis and a review of their compositions gravely settling the pretensions to precedence among them, and placing Dana at their head— Halleck has poetical powers, smothered by a burden of burlesque— Percival has half the property of a poet wild and fanciful conceptions— Peabody has tenderness and pathos for copies of verses, and Bryant has some talent at description— With the exception of Halleck, it would take nine such Poets to make a Tale— There was an Ode of Percivals called Genius waking which has acquired some reputation— Tis Pindars Eagle; stolen from Gray, and scourged round the welkin, through every medium of passage, and among the rest through rocks. I read Gray’s Bard, and his Progress of Poesy which I have always admired not only as beautiful poems, but as the best English exemplifications of the Pindaric Ode— My diary has been running in arrear nearly for a Month— I keep it along only by minutes on the loose sheet; and in this book am now as far back as the 14th of September.
11. V. Tuesday.

Finished the version of the 29th. Psalm— Rain storm all day. A Mr Richard Frost from the State of Maine was here. He came to make enquiries concerning a claim for lands, somewhere, which he stated to have been granted by the British Government, to his father before our Revolution for services during the seven years war from 1756 to 1763.—and which he thinks the Son of his brother has fraudulently obtained, by representing himself or his father as the sole heir, to the exclusion of co-heirs equally entitled— The evidence upon which he believes this incredible tale was so exceedingly slight, that I felt ashamed of controverting it— Mr Frost with as little foundation seemed to think that there might be at the public Offices in Washington some documentary Official papers to support his claim, I told him that if there were such documents, they must be among the records of some of the State Governments, or of the British Provinces, and the Office of the Colonial Department in England— Deacon Spear and his brother William were here— The Deacon gave me an account of his Sales of standing-wood upon the Lawyers common, amounting to 494.50. I answered a Letter from Revd. Jacob Norton in which he had enclosed a proposal from his Son, a printer, now living in Georgia, to print my projected biography of my father; I returned likewise to Gray and Bowen 12 pages proof of my Chapter for the American Annual Register, which they had sent me, and I have revised. I sent 8 pages more of manuscript.
12. V:45. Wednesday.

Began the version of the 30th. Psalm— The weather was all day clearing up—ending with cold. I answered a Letter from Richard Henry Lee, and wrote one to James Kent of New-York, and formerly Chancellor of that State— He was some years since superannuated out of that Office, by attaining sixty years of age at which by the Constitution of that State, all judicial offices are vacated. He was then appointed the Professor of Law at Columbia College, and delivered Lectures the substance of which he has published in four Volumes of Commentaries upon the Law— He sent me a copy of the first Volume, when it was published in 1828.— I was then President and postponed acknowledging the receipt of it, for the purpose of reading it; for which I never found time— This inattention was never repaired, but I sent him last Summer copies of my Oration and Eulogy— He has recently delivered an Address to the ΦB.K of Yale College, of which he sent me a copy; and I now write to acknowledge the receipt of it, and to account as well as I can for my former neglect. With the Letter to R. H. Lee, I sent him a second Copy of my Oration, and also of my Eulogy— I walked this Evening with Isaac H. Adams to my brother’s— Dr Holbrook came this afternoon to visit Mrs Nowlan who is ill with a racking cough.
13. V:50. Thursday.

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dinner— Mr and Mrs Frothingham came out from Boston, and dined with us— They brought with them their two youngest children. There was some music of the Piano, and singing, by Mrs Frothingham and Mary Roberdeau; from which I had formed some expectations of amusement to myself which were disappointed— Mr Alexander Townsend came out to visit me, and remained and dined with me— This gentleman is a lawyer in Boston of great eccentricity of character— I have a very slight acquaintance with him, but on two or three different occasions he has manifested a regard and friendship for me which is entitled to my gratitude— He came now to visit me in consequence of my civil answer to his enthusiastic Letter upon my declining the Anti-masonic nomination.— He told me that he himself had informed Governor Lincoln, who was his Classmate at Cambridge, of my having declined— He says Lincoln told him he had been informed that the Anti-Masons, although resolved to oppose his re-election, were not absolutely hostile to him, but intended he should have something else; but he did not say what. Townsend intimated a design to invite me, and some of his friends to dine with him, at the Marlborough Hotel; but I told him I proposed to leave home for the South on the 28th. of this month. He mentioned to me that his Sister Eliza, had published in the Palladium some verses upon my father’s death. Mr Townsend’s visit would have been more agreeable had it not accidentally crossed that of Mr and Mrs Frothingham— They all returned to Boston early after dinner— I sent by Mr Frothingham, revised, the second twelve pages of the chapter for the American Annual Register, to Gray and Bowen from whom I had received the proofs. With them, I sent eight pages more of Manuscript. I am still hammering upon that anvil. Coll and Mrs Quincy called early in the Evening, to take leave— They are about leaving their Summer residence to take up their abode for the winter at Boston— Mr Thomas Greenleafs two daughters, Mr Beale and his daughter, my brothers Son Thomas and his daughter Elizabeth and Mary Harrod spent the Evening here.
14. IV:30. Friday.

Finished the version of the 30th. Psalm—very bad. And wrote in Mary Roberdeau’s Album a translation of the French Sonnet La belle matineuse, which notwithstanding the Criticism of Lord Kaimes I think very beautiful— Its beauty consists in the minute description of a clear and splendid rising of the Sun— It is eminently picturesque and has perhaps a charm to me because a clear Sunrise is always to me an object of pleasure— I rank it among the enjoyments of life, and therefore sympathise more than Lord Kaimes could do with the magnificence of the picture in the french Sonnet— My nephew the Lieutt. was here; and the day was one which passed over me with more tranquility and composure than many others. I received a Letter and proof sheet of the History of the Indians from T. L. M’Kenney I revised the proof and enclosed it back to him with a Letter— I received also a Letter from Eastburn, requesting a revised copy of the Eulogy, of which he proposes to strike off a new Edition; and I received from Alexander Townsend a book; several lithographic Prints, and a copy of the verses of his Sister upon the death of my father. Planted 3 Butternuts and 3 rows of Acorns in the Nursery.
15. V:15. Saturday.

Began the version of the 31st. Psalm— This day my Son Charles with his wife and child, who have spent the last Month with us, left us to return to their residence in Boston. It left a painful void in the house. Their Society is extremely pleasing to me, and in proportion as we grow old, the want of Society, and the aversion to Solitude increase. Louisa C. Smith dined with us— Alpheus Spear was here in the afternoon— Planted Acorns in my Nursery, and walked in the Evening to my brother’s who is again very ill. I received Letters from Thomas S. Grimke of Charleston South-Carolina—from President Josiah Quincy at Cambridge—From R. Rush, and from Dr David Hosack of New-York— I answered the Letter of J. H. Eastburn, and sent him a revised copy of the Eulogy; and the Letter from President Quincy which proposed that Ward N. Boylston should take private Lessons of Instruction in the Mathematics to enable him to keep up in the public exercises in that Department with his Class.
16. IV.45. Sunday

Heard Dr Richmond of Dorchester this morning from Psalm 39.7. “And now Lord, what wait I for? my hope is in thee”—and in the afternoon from Luke 12.57. “Yea, and why even of yourselves judge ye not what is right?” sober and judicious Sermons; the latter upon the right and duty of private judgment in matters of religion.— Dr. Richmond dined with us, and I had some conversation upon the Trinitarian and Unitarian Controversy— Louisa Smith also dined with us. In the Evening my nephew Thomas B. Adams junr. the Lieutt. came to take leave of us. His furlough is about to expire and he is to depart to-morrow, to return to his Post at Fort Moultrie, on Sullivans Island near Charleston South-Carolina— Mr Beale and his daughter Ann were also here this Evening.
17. V. Monday.

Lieutenant Thomas B. Adams junr. departed this morning to return to his station— Mr Carr came and agreed to take a lease of my homestead farm for three or five years— Isaac Farrar’s lease will expire the first of April next: and as I have not had reason to be satisfied with him as a tenant I have concluded not to renew it— I agreed with Carr about the terms and engaged to draw up a lease to be signed by us both— Mr Tufts of Weymouth was here with his daughter Mercy— He asked me for the papers relating to our Uncle Norton Quincy’s will and Estate which he had some time since lent me; but I had them not at hand— I wrote Letters to Captain Alden Partridge, and to Mr W. H. Seward, in answer to Letters received them— I declined accepting an election as a member of a new Literary Institution founded by Captain Partridge, at his Military Academy; because in some Resolutions adopted at the time of its foundation there were censorious and unjust reflections upon the ordinary course of instruction pursued at our Universities and Colleges— Mr Seward had written to me from Boston a few days after he was here— My Answer has been delayed, not knowing where to address it— He has since been to the Anti-masonic Convention at Baltimore— Mrs Adams went to an evening fishing party, and Miss Roberdeau passed the Evening abroad. I walked to my brother’s but did not see him, as he was asleep. He is again very ill.
18. IV:15. Tuesday.

Deacon Spear was here, and settled with me for the late Sale of standing wood on the Lawyer’s common by part-payment; and his Note payable without interest the first of May next for the remainder— His brother William was with him, and I engaged him to cut and cart wood in the ensuing winter for the consumption of my house next year. Mr. Edward Miller and Mr Gourgas called together— Mr Miller has removed with his family for the Winter into Boston. He is going to New-York, and I requested him to engage for us Apartments, a parlour and two bed-chambers at the City Hotel or at Hamilton’s for Sunday the 30th. of this Month, and to give me notice of it by a line, which he promised to do. Jonathan Baxter came for his tax bill which I paid— Louisa C. Smith, and Elizabeth C. Adams were here in the afternoon, and also Mr Beale and Mr Gourgas— I walked to Mr John Greenleaf’s where I found Mrs Patten Hall, and invited her to dine with us to-morrow— She is spending a few days at Mr Greenleafs— I planted three rows of Acorns in my Nursery— Wrote Letters to Dr David Hosack, and to Charles Miner.
19. IV:15. Wednesday.

Jacob Loring was an old Soldier of the Revolutionary War from Plympton in the County of Plymouth who has an application before Congress for a Pension— His evidence of service is somewhat defective and I advised him to obtain more of it, if he can, and forward it to me at Washington— Mrs Hall and Louisa C. Smith dined with us— After dinner Mr and Mrs Potter called; with Mr Marston— Mr Potter had a new Subscription paper for the building of the new Episcopal Church, and materially varying from the terms of the former Subscription. They were desirous of erecting a Stone Church, but have ascertained that their funds will not warrant them in undertaking it— They have concluded to build of wood, but now there has arisen a question what allowance shall be made to the holders of pews in the present Church, for relinquishing them and the new Subscription paper
contained an agreement that the usual allowance should be made from the funds on that account— I declined subscribing to it for two reasons—first because I had no property or concern in the present Church—and secondly because the proposed engagement was so loosely expressed that I thought it more likely to cause difficulty than to remove it Mr Beale and his daughter and Miss Otis spent the Evening here— I answered a Letter from Joseph Blunt, about his writing a Life of my father for the family Library of the Harper’s.
20. V. Thursday.

Went to Boston with Mrs Adams and Mary Roberdeau— Calls at Gray and Bowen’s—Lord’s and at J. H. Eastburn’s. I returned to Gray and Bowen 12 pages of proof of the chapter for the American Annual Register— Eastburn has not yet put to press the second Edition of the Eulogy on James Monroe, but proposes to do it immediately— He told me of a Grocer who had purchased 12 Copies of the Eulogy, and within these 3 days had advertised for sale his whole stock—at reduced prices— He found upon enquiry that his whole stock consisted of seven copies in bad condition— We all went to Medford and dined with Mr P. C. Brooks and a family party. Charles’s wife with her child went in our Carriage with Mrs Adams and Mary Roberdeau and I went in a Chaise with Charles— Peter C. Brooks junr and his wife have passed the Summer at Medford with Mr Brooks. We had little time to stay— On our return we stopp’d at Mr John Angiers, and left Miss Roberdeau there to pass two or three days with Mrs Angier— Mr Gourgas and Elizabeth C. Adams came in from Quincy while we were there— We returned to Boston, and leaving Charles and his family at his house, Mrs Adams and myself came home in the Evening to Quincy— I finished this morning the version of the 31st Psalm.
21. V. Friday.— Saw Venus. Morning Star.

Began the version of the 32d. Psalm— Business presses upon me as the time approaches of my departure for Washington. Alpheus Spear was here and settled for his Rent the last Quarter.— The Deacon called, and was going to make sale for me of some standing wood. Dr. Holbrook called—my brother is again extremely ill— Dr Holbrook thinks it not probable that he will recover— His family is much distressed, and his condition is a melancholy contemplation for me— I feel it my duty not to repine at the dispensations of Providence; but they bear upon me, through almost every one with whom I am connected— I walked this Evening to Mr Marston’s, where I met Mr and Mrs John Greenleaf and Mrs Hall; and thence to my brother’s; but he was asleep and I did not see him— Mr Potter the Episcopal Clergyman came in while I was there— I finished this day the 21st. Chapter of the American Annual Register, which has occupied me these six weeks— This, with the Oration for the 4th. of July and the Eulogy upon James Monroe have absorbed the whole Summer, and totally suspended the biography of my father.
22. IV:45. Saturday.

William Oaks, from Bangor in the State of Maine, came with another man, and was the person having the claims to Lands under grants from the British Government, and of which he supposes himself to have been defrauded by his brother’s Son, which I erroneously attributed on the 11th. instt. to the man named Frost. what I there said of him applies only to this man. Mr Carr came and I executed with him a lease of my homestead farm for three or five years from the first of April next.— Mr Bailey was here on Thursday while I was gone to Medford— This afternoon I rode over to his house at Dorchester, but he was in Boston. I wrote to Edward Ingersoll— My correspondence still absorbs my time.
23. IV. Sunday.

I went into Boston this morning, with Mrs Adams and Mrs Nowlan.— Attended at Mr Frothingham’s Church.— Charles’s new born daughter was baptized by him, by the name of Louisa Catherine; and his own daughter, born a few days before, by the name of Ann Brooks— The two Sisters held their own Children— Mr Frothingham took his child into his own arms, and Charles held his— The Service began with these baptisms— Mr Frothingham afterwards preached an excellent Sermon from Titus 2.14 “Who gave himself for us, that he might redeem us from all iniquity, and purify unto himself a peculiar people, zealous of good works.” The peculiarity of the Christian Institution, as characterized by zeal for good works, formed the subject of the discourse, and was presented in a variety of very interesting points of view— Among the rest an ingenious argument was deduced from the position in the text, that as zeal for good works was pointed out as emphatically the peculiar excellence of Christianity, it was a conclusive consideration that it did not consist in speculative opinions or controvertible metaphysical doctrines— The beneficent effects of Christianity upon the human character and upon the life of men in its various relations was set forth with great eloquence— Miss Roberdeau was there; but the Sermon was too wide from Calvinism to please her— She came from Mrs Angier’s at Medford last Evening, and is now on a visit to Mrs Edward Miller. We dined at my Son Charles’s, and I went with him again after dinner to Mr Frothingham’s Church, where we heard Mr Greenwood, from Psalm 42.2. “My Soul thirsteth for God, for the living God: when shall I come and appear before God?” The composition of the discourse was not entirely at variance with the tone of the text, but it contrasted strangely with the coldness of the delivery— I returned in the Evening with Mrs Adams to Quincy, leaving Mrs Nowlan in Boston— This morning I finished the version of the 32d. Psalm— I wrote this Morning to Thomas S. Grimke of Charleston S.C.
24. IV:15. Monday.

Began the version of the 33d. Psalm.— Deacon Spear called, and paid me 35 dollars .24 Cents on account of a second and small Sale of standing wood, and gave me his note payable 1. May 1832 for 86 dollars— W. Spear his brother engaged to cut and bring me wood for the next Summer— Mr Oakman is a Petitioner to Congress for a pension for military Service during the revolutionary War—as usual with almost a total deficiency of Evidence— I told him that which it would be necessary for him to procure, and assured him that if he would forward it to me at Washington I would attend as well as I could to his petition. Mr Marston came here, with his kinsman Mr Josiah Randall of
Philadelphia Mr Randall has come to place his daughter at Miss Marston’s School and departs for his return home to-morrow— I gave him copies of my Oration and Eulogy upon Mr Monroe which I had been keeping for him some time— I had with him a warm though friendly discussion upon the subject of Free-Masonry and Anti-Masonry.— He is a Mason of high order and has been many years Grand Master of a lodge at Philadelphia. He says there is a Letter from Mr Clay, disapproving the Statements made by his friends Genl. Peter B. Porter and W. B. Rochester of his opinions upon Masonry— Mrs Adams went to Boston this Morning taking with her Mrs Pitts, and our granddaughter Louisa. She intended to have returned this Evening, but there was a heavy storm of rain which detained her at Boston. I wrote a Letter to Professor Follen at Cambridge
25. V. Tuesday

Finished the reading of the Bible, which I began in August of the last year— I hope that the reading of this book is never wholly unprofitable to me, but I am conscious that I do not derive from it so much profit as Sought. The version that I am now making of the Psalms was undertaken partly with a view to impress more deeply upon my own mind the Sentiments they contain. The reading of three chapters, and the version of one Stanza, twice written down occupy me from an hour and a half to two hours every day. I believe there is none of my time better spent: and yet I would I were capable of application to it, tenfold more intense— It would then produce some fruit— Mrs Adams with Miss Roberdeau and the child returned this morning from Boston.— I wrote Letters to R Rush and to William Plumer— In the afternoon I went with Isaac H. Adams to the Mount Wollaston farm, and planted apple-seeds in the hills where those planted last year failed to come up, or where those that did come up have perished, that is to say almost all— My plantations I perceive will come to nothing— I began with them too late in life— I have no one to follow them up with the same interest that I take in them— I am absent half the year, and they require incessant attention the whole year round. And other necessary occupations draw away my attention from this— After planting the seeds, I walked with I. H. Adams to my brothers and found him better.— Mr Bailey was here this Evening and gave me some particulars of the proceedings of the Antimasonic Convention at Baltimore— From his account the nomination of Mr Wirt, was a forlorn hope; the only expedient there was to exclude the nomination of John M’lean of Ohio, which Henry Dana Ward and the members of the Convention from New York, had settled before hand— Mr Bailey was not satisfied with the proceedings at Baltimore; nor is he pleased with the nomination of a candidate for the office of Governor of this Commonwealth, in opposition to Lincoln.
26. V. Wednesday.

Began reading the Old Testament again— Three Chapters of Genesis— We are now in the bustle of preparation for departure to spend the Winter at Washington, with the prospect of not being here again before next June. The change is irksome in a high degree— It breaks off from a course of occupation to which habit has formed an attachment, and extinguishes many wise Resolutions— It is however not without its advantages, and Journeying has in itself many pleasures— Dr Holbrook was here and I settled his account, partly of some years standing— Miss Roberdeau
went on a party with Mr Beale to Cohasset, and Nantasket beach— Mr and Mrs James H. Foster were here before dinner.— Mr Foster mentioned the death of Jonathan Mason, yesterday— Mr Webster and Mr Isaac P. Davis paid us visits this afternoon from Boston— I transplanted part of the seedling trees from boxes into the Garden; but the time fails me for almost all the arrangements I proposed to make; both of my trees, and of my seeds for plantation. Mr Beale and his daughter Ann spent the Evening here, and Louisa C. Smith stays till our departure— I wrote part of a Letter to W. Plumer junr.
27. IV:30. Thursday.

Harvey Field came with a parish tax-bill of 150 dollars—for which I gave him orders upon William Field and Joseph Hardwick; and requested him to apply to Alpheus Spear, for his portion of the tax; which they have assessed upon me— Deacon Spear came for orders about a further sale of standing wood.— I had authorised him to collect the Rents due to me, from William Field and Joseph Hardwick, but they refused to pay them— Mr Beale who is now the parish Treasurer, paid me a year’s interest on the Note due to me from the Parish; and I paid away that and all other monies I had in bills, coming in at the moment of my departure. I went to Boston, and took up from my Son Charles 300 dollars for the expenses of our Journey to Washington— Called at Mr Bond’s shop, and took my Chronometer, which he has had three weeks to repair— The main spring was broken, by an original defect in the steel.— It has been in use less than six years, and ought to have lasted sixty. Bond charged me twelve dollars for the new Spring— I went to the Boston Press Office, and directed that the paper should henceforth be sent to me at Washington. I found the Anti-masonic Committee assembled together, and had some conversation with them— They were flattering themselves, that Mr Clay would withdraw, or be withdrawn, as a Candidate for the Presidency, and that Mr Wirt would be nominated by the Convention to meet at Baltimore next December— I assured them it was impossible. Dr Phelps shewed me a Letter from John C Spencer urging strongly that this should be done as of infinite importance— Phelps asked me, whether if I, and Mr Webster, and Mr Everett, should advise Mr Clay to withdraw he would not do so— I told him I should give Mr Clay no such advice, nor did I believe that Mr Webster or Mr Everett would—but that if we should Mr Clay would not take our advice— I believed further that Mr Clay’s party would not suffer him to withdraw if he would.— I called also at Gray and Bowen’s; and received the last proof-sheets of the Chapter for the North American Register— Returned to Quincy to dine. Joseph Angier with Mrs Angier and Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us— They and Mr Beale spent the Evening here— They discoursed most excellent Music, but business crowded upon me so that I could not be with them— I was confined to my chamber. A clergyman by the name of Jonathan Leslie, from Unionville Ohio, came with a subscription paper for building a Church there, and proposed taking his lodging at my house this Night. I gave a small contribution for his Church, and greatly regretted that I could not give him the lodging that he requested; every bed-room in the house being already occupied. I was engaged till near midnight in my chamber— Finished the Letter to William Plumer jr. revised the proof sheets for the American annual Register— Answered a Letter from William L. Stone at New-York— Partly packed my trunk; and wrote half a Letter to Charles.
28. IV:45. Friday— From Quincy to Dedham.

Before leaving home I finished my version of the 33d. Psalm. Mrs Adams departed about nine this Morning, with our own Carriage and pair of horses—with John Kirk, Mrs Nowlan, Mrs Pitts and my Son John’s infant daughter, Mary Louisa.— She intended if possible to reach Providence this Evening— So that the horses might have a Night’s rest before being embarked in the Steam-boat— I finished my packing— Left Mrs Kirk who is perhaps to go and live with Charles— Isaac Farrar came in, and agreed to take all necessary care of the house during the winter, and to deliver up the farm house and farm to Mr Carr on the first of April next— I had paid off Salmon Farrar to the end of this month and left directions for him to block up the external cellar doors and windows with Sea-weed, and to cover the seedling plants in the Garden— But I have been obliged to leave my plantations greatly neglected, and fear they will come to nought. I have agreed to pay for Isaac H. Adams’s board at his father’s house 3. dollars a week, during the winter, and he is to copy my fathers Journals— We dined early and at 3. O’Clock Gillet sent a Coach and pair of horses with which I came with Mary Roberdeau to Bride’s Hotel at Dedham. We found my brothers youngest son Joseph Harrod had rode with the driver, and he returned with him to Quincy— We reached Dedham just before Sunset and took lodgings at Bride’s for the Night— We had scarcely alighted when a Mr Waite came in, with a Mr Whitcomb from Boston— They had gone out to Quincy to see me there; and arrived just after I had left home— They followed us therefore here— Mr Waite is a son of Thomas B. Waite now deceased, formerly employed by me, when in the Department of State to print the Journal of the Convention of 1787. and the Secret Journals of the Old Congress.— He had previously published ten Volumes of American State Papers of which Congress had taken some hundreds of copies, and then two additional Volumes of which they took few or none, and of which therefore a great portion remain on hand— Mr Waite proposes to petition Congress to take a number of Copies of the 11th. and 12th. Volumes to complete the sets which they had taken of the preceding ten. He asked me if I thought they would take them. I thought it hardly probable— The sets in ten Volumes had been distributed to members of former Congresses, many years ago.— There are very few if any now left in the Library of Congress— So that they would have only all the sets of the two odd Volumes which they should take separated from all the rest— Mr Waite made also some enquiries and observations concerning the political state of Europe—France—England—Poland; about which all our conjectures are mere pastime. Miss Roberdeau retired before 8 O’Clock in the Evening to bed; and Mr J. H. Cobb afterwards called and invited me to go and see his Machinery for the manufactory of sewing Silk, and of Silk fringe— I accordingly went with him and saw his spinning winding and reeling machines in two separate buildings— His establishment is upon a large scale, and he proposes to enlarge it still farther— He has an Englishman with him from Spitalfields who has been several years in this Country— Mr. Cobb gave me a copy of the manual for the raising of Silkworms published by direction of the Legislature of Massachusetts— After returning to Bride’s, I had still a remnant of evening to pass, and wrote a minute for the diary of the day, marking in it that Deacon Josiah Adams came this morning and I had discourse with
him about Oak trees dying from the top, and firewood— Our accounts to be settled next Spring or Summer— Isaac Farrar is to settle accounts at the end of his Lease with my Son Charles— Louisa C. Smith and Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us and Ann Beale came after dinner to take leave of Miss Roberdeau. Mr Wait told me that an Act had passed in the United States Senate for taking 500 copies of the 11th. and 12th. Volumes of the State papers but did not get through the house— He intends to Memorialize Congress again to take his books, and asked for my support which I promised him— He said there was an Article in the last Edinburgh Review, by Lord Chancellor Brougham upon vested Rights and Titles. Mr Cobb’s workman from London, is skilful in the business— His name is Edward Brown— I saw some very handsome fringe of their making—4000 Cocoons make a pound of Silk— Sometimes 3000.—even 2500.—one Pound of raw silk makes 90 yards of fringe which sells at 1 1/4 dollar a yard— Cobb has been engaged six years in this business and says it is profitable— Spoke of the Morus Multicaulis or Chinese Mulberry as the best for the worm— It grows as a shrub. Brown has been in this Country five years; and told me that he had children born here, and would never leave the Country— After finishing my notices for the day, I made a version of one Stanza of Psalm 34. I have determined to make the experiment of continuing while travelling this portion of my occupations. There is time in Steam-boats and Stages, and at public houses which it seems to me may be well devoted to precisely such employment— I therefore purchased the other day an Episcopalian Prayer-book which contains the Psalms translated from the Septuagint or the Latin Vulgate, and I take this with me in my pocket— I also bought George R. Noyes’s new prose version of the Psalms—but that I packed in my small trunk to be sent round to Washington by water— My evening passed away very rapidly.
29. IV. Saturday— From Dedham to Providence— Steam-boat Boston— CaptainSound.

Though I rose thus early my Morning was as short as had been the Evening. I shaved myself and made a version or one Stanza of Psalm 34— Roused Miss Roberdeau at 6. and at 7. breakfasted with the Passengers of the Stages from Boston going to Providence— In one of these two Seats had been taken by my Son Charles’s direction in Boston, for Miss Roberdeau and myself to take us up at Dedham— In this we started from Bride’s at 7. O’Clock and at 20 minutes past eleven, alighted at the Steamboat wharf at Providence— The Night had been sharp—the day was cold and clear, and there was a skin of ice over the ditches along the sides of the road— Our Stage company was taciturn and unsociable beyond every thing I had ever witnessed, and excepting slight occasional conversation between Miss Roberdeau and me, we had a silent ride— I pointed out to her the last view of the blue-hills as they were seen from the borders of Dedham and Walpole, and fell into a reverie, enquiring of myself what it was that gave to those hills such power of touching sensibility as I always experience at their first and final appearance coming to or going from home.— I traced the sensation to the spot of my nativity at the foot of Penn’s Hill— I composed five Stanza’s, upon the village on that spot between Dedham and Providence— We found
Mrs Adams, and the family with her: the Carriage and horses already embarked. They had slept last Night at Pawtucket; the bridge there being in a process of repairs. At ten minutes past Noon the boat left the wharf, and at half past two reached Newport—proceeded immediately with fine wind and fair weather; but blowing almost a gale, and too cold for remaining long on the decks— Of our fellow passengers, there was Robert Apthorp, Son of Coll. John T. Apthorp a young man of about 20. going to New-York to embark for Europe— He is one alone remaining of several children who just at that period of life have fallen into consumptions and perished— His own Constitution is very delicate and his parents are in continual fear of losing him the same way— They took him to Europe themselves the last year, whence they returned in the Spring and he is now going alone— Mr and Mrs Abbot of Michillimackinac, acquaintances of the Boyd family. Captain Cobbs of the United States Army—and others unknown— The boat not very full— The Boston, is a new Boat more tremulous and noisy and therefore more unpleasant to passengers than any other of the modern Sound-faring Steamers— The passage round Point Judith was rough, and the swell considerable; but early in the Evening the boat entered the Sound, opposite New-London after which the motion was less uncomfortable— Kept in the Cabin by the weather; and finding little conversation with the passengers, I wrote out the five Stanza’s upon Penn’s valley that I had composed in the Stage, and in the course of the Evening compos’d three more— Before retiring for the Night I versified also one Stanza of the 34th. Psalm— The time passed with me cheerily.
30. V:30. Sunday. New-York.

I had as usual little sleep last Night in the boat; and towards morning composed three Stanzas more of the lines upon Penn’s Valley— We landed at New-York this morning about 6 O’Clock or just at the dawn of day— We came immediately to the Washington Hotel, kept by Hamilton and took the apartments which Edward Miller had engaged for us— A few minutes after we arrived, Major Fanning C. Tucker came and took Miss Roberdeau with him to Brookline where he resides— Shortly after I received a note from George Sullivan, who with his family lives at the house where we lodge, and who offered to accompany me to Church. I wrote out the remaining Stanzas on Penns Valley; and then went with Mr Sullivan, to hear Mr Hawks a celebrated preacher, but he was absent gone to preach at Bridgport— We then went to Grace Church and heard Dr Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright from Romans 7.6. “But now we are delivered from the law, that being dead wherein we were held; that we should serve in newness of spirit, and not in the oldness of the Letter”— Dr Mayhew is an excellent preacher—a grandson of the eminent Dr Mayhew of Boston, and son to a Lady long an intimate friend of my Mother’s— I saw George Blake at Church; who is a member of the Tariff Convention now sitting in this City. Returning from Church I met Mr Philip Hone, formerly Mayor of New-York, and now one of its eminent Citizens. After Church, Mr and Mrs George Sullivan paid us visits, as did Alexander H. Everett a member of the Tariff Convention and Joseph Blunt— He came again this Evening, and attended me to the Unitarian Church, where I heard Mr William Ware from 2. Peter 1.4. “Whereby are given unto us exceeding great and precious promises; that by these ye might be partakers of the divine nature; having escaped the corruption that is in the world through lust:” Mr Ware’s Sermon was ingenious—the delivery cold and inanimate.
31. Monday: V.15.

Finished the version of the 34th. Psalm— I received two successive invitations from Mr Hamblin, the manager of the Bowery Theatre, to attend a Representation there, with offers to select for performance any one of several plays which I should prefer— After once declining I finally consented to go this Evening; the performance to be without alteration for me and no notice to be publicly given of my attendance.— I received also a written invitation signed by William Wilkins, President of the Tariff Convention, to attend at their Meeting within the bar— I went accordingly about 11. O’Clock; but being alone, and having some difficulty in finding the Hall since they were in Session, I finally went in among the Spectators below the bar; and being seen there by Mr James Tallmadge one of the Vice-Presidents he came to me, and introduced me to a seat immediately behind the President within the bar— As I passed through the Hall, the members all rose, and on my taking the seat offered me gave a general manifestation of applause— Mr Charles J. Ingersoll of Philadelphia, was reading an Address to the People of the United States—in which he had made much progress, and which he continued to read for about one hour and a half longer—after the reading was closed there was much applause; and short speeches made by several members— Suggestions of slight amendments to avoid reflections upon The Anti-tariff Convention lately held at Philadelphia, and propositions for having forty thousand copies of the Address printed by H. Niles at Baltimore—one of the Secretaries of the Convention— This body consisted of upwards of 530 members, but they have been sitting ever since the 26th. and I was told that upwards of an hundred members were already gone— Among the members I recognized Jonathan Roberts. H. W. Dwight James D’Wolfe Joseph Hemphill, R. G. Shaw—James T Austin and some others— Mr C. A. Davis began the reading of a Report, and I came away.— At my Lodgings I received visits from B. W. Crowninshield, Dr Wainwright. Dr and Mrs Beck daughter of Major Tucker, and the Miss Tucker, with whom I travelled on the 4th. of December 1829 from New-York to Philadelphia, and to whom I then addressed some verses, which she never saw till Miss Roberdeau lately sent her a copy of them— She thanked me for them now. Mr and Mrs Hosack—Mr Philip Hone and the Revd. Mr. Matthews— I found a Note from Mr James Kent, late Chancellor of the State inviting me to dine with him— After dinner I paid visits to Mr Gallatin, at whose house I met Jonathan Roberts; and to Mr James Kent whom I found in his Study, and with whom I had curious conversation. He is preparing a new Edition of his Law Commentaries—and being in wit a man, simplicity a child—we talked half-wisely half childishly about his Commentaries; about Civil and Common Law—about Shakespear, Yale College, the Φ.B.K. Society and his address to them and many other puerilities— I promised to dine with him to-morrow— I returned to my Lodgings, and went with Mrs Adams, Miss Roberdeau and Joseph Blunt to the Bowery Theatre, where we saw Venice Preserv’d; and a German performer of Attitudes which pass by the name of the living Statue— A new species of exhibition, or at least one that I had never witness’d before. There is a Pedestal for a Monument on which the man dressed in a Garb, and coloured like Plaster stood; and threw himself successively into the attitudes of celebrated
marble statues of antiquity, such as the fighting and the dying gladiator; the quoit-player, the knife-grinder, and the attitudes of some of the personages in David’s pictures— After this was over we came away before the farce began— The house was tolerably filled but not crowded— There was a militia-company which had been parading in one of the boxes— After the first act of the Tragedy was over, a man started up in the Pit, and said Three Cheers for John Quincy Adams; upon which they all rose waved round their hats and huzz’ad—immediately after which a man behind me in the same box cried out—Three cheers for Andrew Jackson; and they gave three huzza’s more. All this I took for a farcical part of the Entertainment arranged by the Manager, as a compliment to me and at the same time to do honour to the President of the United States. It was about eleven O’Clock when we returned to our lodgings— Miss Roberdeau had spent the day here, and stays over Night— I received this Morning a Letter from T. L. M’Kenney of Philadelphia; and one from my Son John at Washington— This last mentioned the illness of his youngest child in terms which alarmed us; and Mrs Adams determined to leave me here, and go on immediately to Philadelphia, and probably to Washington.— She has great confidence in her own nursing of Children; and still more in that of Mrs Nowlan. We had proposed to pass some days, perhaps weeks at Philadelphia; but this illness of our Sons child disconcerts all our purposes— She has been very sick for two or three Months; and her mother has also been dangerously ill— My Son has had a Summer of severe trials— My own has not been light.

Day— The Winter change in my Life is coming on again— The time of the first fortnight of this Month was occupied as in the preceding Months— The remainder in keeping up my Correspondence, and in preparations for this Journey.— I have now found the means of making some use of the Time passed in Steam-boats and Stages.— Very doubtful whether better than none— The less I leave myself of Time to think, the less waste I have of thoughts in dejection and despondency— Yet I cannot keep them all off.
